Since the dictionary is not really my 'friend," yet, I we=
nt right to my old standby, Henri Joly.

The kanji used are shown in Joly's=
 "Legend in Japanese Art" under his entry for Rokurokubi:

http://bit.ly/7K=
j6QG

The link is to the scanned copy at archive.org, which is the 1908 edi=
tion, on p. 291. It's on p. 433 of the reprint editions by Tuttle. Joly cat=
egorizes Rokurokubi, "long-necked goblin," as Bakemono, or "transformed thi=
ngs," which include all manner of ghosts, goblins, etc., which he covered m=
ore fully in a paper presented to the Japan Society in 1909, printed in the=
 Transactions, Vol. IX.

You can never have too many reference books!

Crai=
g
